chapter.title: 36 Aggregatibacter, Capnocytophaga, Eikenella, Kingella, Pasteurella, and Other Fastidious or Rarely Encountered Gram-Negative Rods*

sect1.title: 36 Aggregatibacter, Capnocytophaga, Eikenella, Kingella, Pasteurella, and Other Fastidious or Rarely Encountered Gram-Negative Rods*
sect1.para: The bacterial genera covered in this chapter are taxonomically diverse and belong to the familiesCardiobacteriaceae, Flavobacteriaceae, Leptotrichiaceae, Neisseriaceae, Pasteurellaceae, and Porphyromonadaceae; common traits justify their discussion as a group. Except for Chromobacterium and some Pasteurella spp., for aerobic growth they require supplemented media, and they often grow slowly (48 h at 35 to 37oC); they fail to grow on MacConkey and eosin-methylene blue agar. A 5 to 10% CO2 atmosphere may be necessary for growth initiation and improves growth on subculture. Apart from Chromobacterium spp., they do not possess flagella, but some may show gliding or twitching motility, resulting in limited spreading of colonies and pitting of the agar surface. Identification of those genera is difficult by conventional phenotypic methods. Commercially available systems (1, 2) allow identification of the frequently encountered human species, including the HACEK organisms (Haemophilus spp., Aggregatibacter spp., Cardiobacterium spp., Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella spp.), causing infective endocarditis (3). If accurate identification of uncommon isolates is a concern, molecular methods, e.g., 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing may be necessary (4). Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF-MS) can be helpful (5, 6). The patterns of the cellular fatty acids are no longer routinely used; information on cellular fatty acids can be found in chapter 32 of the 10th edition of this manual. This chapter focuses on species commonly isolated from humans.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The taxonomy of the familyPasteurellaceae has undergone important changes (http://www.the-icsp.org/taxonomic-subcommittees) (7); the family consists of over 100 named species distributed in over 25 genera, of which 4 include human pathogens: Actinobacillus, Aggregatibacter, Haemophilus, and Pasteurella. Many taxa of this family, Pasteurellaceae, are in the process of being or have recently been classified; e.g., bacteria of Bisgaard taxa 5 and 7 have been classified as Caviibacterium pharyngocola gen. nov., sp. nov. and Conservatibacter flavescens gen. nov., sp. nov., respectively (8) (but are not included in this chapter). Aggregatibacter spp., formerly named Haemophilus spp. (9), are included. The genus Haemophilus, as presently constituted, is described in chapter 37 of this Manual. Neisseria spp. with rod forms, i.e., Neisseria elongata subsp. glycolytica and Neisseria elongata subsp. nitroreducens, Neisseria weaveri, and Neisseria animaloris (10), are described in chapter 35 are included in a differentiation table (see Table 4) in this chapter.

sect1.title: Actinobacillus
sect1.para: The genusActinobacillus in the family Pasteurellaceae consists of facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile, Gram-negative rods and comprises animal (Actinobacillus equuli, Actinobacillus lignieresii, Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae, and Actinobacillus suis) and human (Actinobacillus hominis and Actinobacillus ureae) species but no longer includes Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans (http://www.the-icsp.org/taxonomic-subcommittees) (9). The G+C content of the DNA of Actinobacillus spp. is between 40 and 43 mol% (11).

sect1.title: Aggregatibacter
sect1.para: Multilocus sequence analysis ofA. actinomycetemcomitans, Haemophilus aphrophilus, Haemophilus paraphrophilus, and Haemophilus segnis (9) shows that these bacteria represent a monophyletic group. DNA-DNA relatedness between H. aphrophilus and H. paraphrophilus was 77%, and DNA from H. aphrophilus transformed H. paraphrophilus into an NAD-independent phenotype (9). A. actinomycetemcomitans, H. aphrophilus, H. paraphrophilus, and H. segnis have therefore been transferred into a new genus, Aggregatibacter, in the family Pasteurellaceae, with the species Aggregatibacter aphrophilus comprising the former H. aphrophilus and H. paraphrophilus, i.e., including V factor-dependent and -independent isolates (9). The G+C content of the DNA of Aggregatibacter spp. is 42 to 44 mol% (11). Aggregatibacter kilianii was proposed for human clinical isolates of Aggregatibacter as a new species (12).

sect1.title: Capnocytophaga
sect1.para: The genusCapnocytophaga in the family Flavobacteriaceae at present consists of at least 10 species (Capnocytophaga canimorsus, Capnocytophaga cynodegmi, Capnocytophaga ochracea, Capnocytophaga gingivalis, Capnocytophaga sputigena, Capnocytophaga haemolytica, Capnocytophaga granulosa, and Capnocytophaga leadbetteri) of facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile Gram-negative rods, with gliding motility (13). Capnocytophaga periodontitidis sp. nov. was recently described for two isolates from subgingival plaque in association with severe periodontitis; Capnocytophaga genomospecies AHN8471 might be the same species as C. periodontitidis (13). Capnocytophaga canis and Capnocytophaga stomatis have been proposed as new species of dog- and cat-hosted isolates (14, 15). Capnocytophaga felis sp. nov. was recently described for four isolates from oral cavities of healthy cats in Japan (16). The G+C content of the DNA of this genus is 34 to 44 mol% (17).

sect1.title: Cardiobacterium
sect1.para: The genusCardiobacterium in the family Cardiobacteriaceae consists of facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile, Gram-negative rods, with two species, Cardiobacterium hominis and Cardiobacterium valvarum (18). The G+C content of the DNA of these species is 59 to 60 mol% (19).

sect1.title: Chromobacterium
sect1.para: The genusChromobacterium in the family Neisseriaceae contains several facultatively anaerobic, motile species, of which Chromobacterium violaceum and Chromobacterium haemolyticum are agents of human disease (20, 21). Their G+C content of the DNA is between 65 and 68 mol% (20).

sect1.title: Dysgonomonas
sect1.para: The genusDysgonomonas in the family Porphyromonadaceae consists of facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile, Gram-negative rods (22). Four species have been isolated from humans: Dysgonomonas capnocytophagoides and Dysgonomonas gadei (23), Dysgonomonas mossii (24), and Dysgonomonas hofstadii (25). The G+C content of the DNA is around 38 mol% (22).

sect1.title: Eikenella
sect1.para: The genusEikenella in the family Neisseriaceae consists of facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile Gram-negative rods. E. corrodens is the most common species. New species isolated from human clinical materials have been described recently as Eikenella exigua sp. nov., Eikenella glucosivorans sp. nov., Eikenella halliae sp. nov., and Eikenella longinqua sp. nov. (26, 27). The G+C content of the DNA of Eikenella spp. is between 55.3 and 58.6 mol% (20, 26, 27).

sect1.title: Kingella
sect1.para: The genusKingella in the family Neisseriaceae consists of the facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile species Kingella kingae, Kingella denitrificans, Kingella oralis, and Kingella potus (20, 28). Kingella negevensis sp. nov. was described for 21 strains cultivated from the oropharynges of healthy children in Israel and Switzerland (29). The G+C content of the DNA of these species is between 45 and 58 mol% (20, 29).

sect1.title: Pasteurella
sect1.para: The taxonomy of the genusPasteurella in the family Pasteurellaceae has been in flux for some time (7, 11) (http://www.bacterio.net). Pasteurella multocida can be separated into P. multocida subsp. multocida, P. multocida subsp. septica, and P. multocida subsp. gallicida; Pasteurella canis, Pasteurella dagmatis, Pasteurella oralis, and Pasteurella stomatis are other species isolated from humans (7). The G+C content of the DNA of Pasteurella spp. is between 38 and 46 mol% (11). New genera or reclassifications may be necessary for species discussed below that are designated with “(P.)” or “(Pasteurella)” (30).

sect1.title: Simonsiella
sect1.para: The genusSimonsiella in the family Neisseriaceae consists of several obligately aerobic species which may show gliding motility (20). The only species isolated from humans is Simonsiella muelleri. This genus has a G+C content of the DNA of 40 to 50 mol% (20).

sect1.title: Streptobacillus
sect1.para: The genusStreptobacillus in the family Leptotrichiaceae consists of facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile Gram-negative rods; Streptobacillus moniliformis and Streptobacillus hongkongensis have been isolated from humans, with a G+C content in their DNA of 25.7 to 28.9% mol% (31). S. hongkongensis has been reclassified as Pseudostreptobacillus hongkongensis gen. nov., comb nov (32). See chapter 57 for the genus Leptotrichia of the family Leptotrichiaceae.

sect1.title: Suttonella
sect1.para: The genusSuttonella in the family Cardiobacteriaceae (19) consists of facultatively anaerobic, nonmotile, Gram-negative rods and so far contains only one human species, Suttonella indologenes (formerly Kingella indologenes) (http://www.bacterio.net). The G+C content of its DNA is 49 mol% (19).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Most bacteria in this group are part of the microbiota of the nasopharynx and/or the oral cavity of animals and/or humans and are nonpathogenic, with the only environmental genus beingChromobacterium spp. Some species of the group are transmitted from animals to humans by bites and licking of wounds, e.g., C. canimorsus (33) and Pasteurella spp. (34) or from humans to humans by droplets, e.g., Kingella spp. (28), or human bites, e.g., E. corrodens (35). They may cause infections anywhere in the human body. Risk factors exist for certain types of septicemia, e.g., liver cirrhosis for P. multocida (36) and neutropenia for oxidase-negative Capnocytophaga spp. (37). Endogenous infections occur as well, e.g., HACEK endocarditis; in a large, multinational cohort study, HACEK organisms were the causes of 1.4% of all cases of endocarditis, characterized by a relatively long interval between first symptoms and diagnosis (range, 2 weeks to 6 months), large vegetation sizes on native or artificial valves of the left side, and frequent embolizations. The prognosis is good with appropriate antibiotic treatment (3).

The habitat ofHaemophilus spp. and Aggregatibacter spp. is the human oral cavity, including dental plaque (9). The normal habitat of Cardiobacterium spp. is the human oral cavity and nasopharynx but possibly also the gastrointestinal and urogenital tracts (19). The natural habitat of E. corrodens is the oral cavities and possibly the gastrointestinal tracts of humans and some mammals, from which it can be transmitted via saliva (bites, syringes) to other individuals (35). Endogenous infections prevail, however. The natural habitat of Kingella spp. is the upper respiratory and oral mucosae of humans and possibly other primates. K. kingae colonizes the throat but not the nasopharynx in many children aged 6 months to 4 years (28). K. negevensis has been isolated from the oropharynges of healthy children (29). K. kingae can be transmitted via respiratory droplets and cause disease outbreaks (38, 39). Variations in oropharyngeal K. kingae colonization rates do not correlate with variations of invasive osteoarticular infections by season or age group (39), although most infections are endogenous. K. oralis has been isolated from the human mouth (20). Suttonella indologenes is not a formal part of HACEK but can cause endocarditis (40). Its natural habitat is unknown (19). A. lignieresii (primary habitat in the oral cavities of sheep and cattle), A. equuli (in the oral cavities of horses and pigs), and A. suis (in the oral cavities of pigs) can be transmitted to humans by animal contact (41). Exclusively human pathogens are A. hominis and A. ureae; their normal habitat is unknown (41, 42).

The oxidase- and catalase-negative speciesC. ochracea, C. gingivalis, C. sputigena, C. haemolytica, C. granulosa, and C. leadbetteri are normal members of the human oral microbiota and can be opportunistic pathogens associated with periodontal diseases (13). C. periodontitidis has been isolated from subgingival plaque of a periodontitis patient (13). The oxidase- and catalase-positive species C. canimorsus and C. cynodegmi reside in the oral cavities of healthy dogs (25% of dogs harbor C. canimorsus as determined by culture, and 85 to 100% of dogs have it as determined by PCR) and cats (15% of cats harbor C. canimorsus as determined by culture) (43).

C. violaceum inhabits soil and water in tropical and subtropical climates between latitudes of 35°N and 35°S (South Africa, Southeast Asia, Australia, southeastern United States, and, rarely, South America) (44). The portal of entry is usually the skin, but oral intake has also been reported (44). The natural habitat of C. haemolyticum is river and lake water, even in temperate regions (45).

MostD. capnocytophagoides strains have been isolated from stools of immunocompromised patients, with a few strains isolated from other sources (46). The natural habitats of this and the other Dysgonomonas spp. are unknown (24, 25).

Pasteurella spp. are widespread in healthy and diseased wild and domestic animals, including rodents, dogs, and cats, inhabiting their nasopharynges and gingivae (11). Human isolates are transmitted predominantly from animals by contact (bites or licking or scratching of wounds). Of the related species (Pasteurella) aerogenes occurs primarily in pigs (34), (Pasteurella) caballi in pigs and equines (34, 47). (P.) pneumotropica has been reclassified as Rodentibacter pneumotropicus comb. nov. and occurs in rodents (30). The natural habitat of (Pasteurella) bettyae is uncertain, but it is detected in genitourinary samples from infected patients, suggesting the possibility of sexual transmission (48).

The natural habitat ofS. muelleri is the oral cavity of humans. In healthy human populations, Simonsiella spp. are found in 30 to 40% of humans, with possibly higher rates in children than in adults. In dogs and cats, Simonsiella spp. are common and abundant (20).

S. moniliformis occurs naturally in the upper respiratory tracts of up to 100% of wild and laboratory rats and other rodents (mice, gerbils, and squirrels) and is occasionally found in dogs and cats that prey on rodents. Transmission to humans occurs either from bites of those animals (rat bite fever) or consumption of contaminated food or water (Haverhill fever) (49).

sect1.title: Actinobacillus spp.
sect1.para: A. lignieresii causes actinobacillosis, a granulomatous disease in cattle and sheep in which, similar to actinomycosis, sulfur granules form in tissues (50). A few human soft tissue infections after a cow or sheep bite or other contacts have been reported (34). A. equuli and A. suis have caused a variety of diseases in horses and pigs; human infections are generally due to horse or pig bites (34) or contact, e.g., a case of meningitis in a child after a visit to a farm (51). A. ureae is most often a commensal in the human respiratory tract, particularly in patients with lower respiratory tract disease (11), but has also been found as an agent of meningitis following trauma or surgery (52) and of other infections in immunocompromised patients (53). A. hominis has also been isolated from such patients but has occurred as a commensal as well, albeit rarely (42). Among members of this genus and other species in the family Pasteurellaceae, virulence factors belonging to the pore-forming protein toxins of the RTX family are widespread. RTX toxins have repeats in the structural toxin peptide and exhibit a cytotoxic and often hemolytic activity (54).

sect1.title: Aggregatibacter spp.
sect1.para: A. actinomycetemcomitans is one of the major agents of juvenile and adult periodontitis (55) and may occur together with Actinomyces spp. in actinomycotic sulfur granules (9). Furthermore, it may cause endocarditis (3), osteomyelitis, arthritis, soft tissue and other infections (55). The leukotoxin A (LtxA) of the RTX family is the main virulence factor but a cytolethal distending toxin (CDT) as well as the lipopolysaccharide and the cytokine-binding factors are also involved in the pathogenicity properties of A. actinomycetemcomitans (56).

A. aphrophilus may cause canniculitis and endophthalmitis as well as systemic diseases, particularly bone and joint infections, spondylodiscitis, brain abscess, peritonitis, and endocarditis (3, 9, 57–60). Aggregatibacter segnis, whose frequency may be underestimated due to apparent misdiagnoses, can cause endocarditis (3, 61). A. segnis may be an important cause of bacteremia and sometimes of other infections (57). A. kilianii was isolated from blood, wounds, abdominal abscess, conjunctivitis, and dacryocystitis (12).

sect1.title: Capnocytophaga spp.
sect1.para: C. gingivalis, C. granulosa, C. haemolytica, C. leadbetteri, C. ochracea, and C. sputigena have been reported as agents of septicemia and other endogenous infections (endocarditis, endometritis, ophthalmic lesions, osteomyelitis, peritonitis, pneumonia, and soft tissue infections) (57, 62–64) in immunocompetent and immunosuppressed (mainly neutropenic) patients. Association with periodontitis is described for C. periodontitidis (13). Infections with C. canimorsus and C. cynodegmi are most commonly associated with dog or cat bites or contact. Patients infected with C. canimorsus most often present with septicemia and have previously been splenectomized or had alcoholic use disorder. In fulminant cases, which have a poor prognosis, disseminated intravascular coagulation, acute renal failure, respiratory distress syndrome, and shock may develop (33). Hemolytic-uremic syndrome and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura are other possible sequelae (33). Aortitis, mycotic aneurysm, endocarditis, blebitis, endophthalmitis, keratitis, meningitis with subsequent sensorineural hearing loss, and peritonitis have been reported as well (33, 65–72). C. cynodegmi has been isolated more rarely, mainly from localized or systemic infections (73). C. canimorsus resists phagocytosis by macrophages and killing by complement and leukocytes; macrophages incubated with the bacterium fail to produce several proinflammatory cytokines (74). C. canis can also induce sepsis or even septic shock; some cases occurred after a cat scratch (75).

sect1.title: Cardiobacterium spp.
sect1.para: Disease caused by bothCardiobacterium spp. is mainly endocarditis (3, 18); vertebral osteomyelitis, discitis, and epidural abscess as a complication of an endocarditis have been described (76). On rare occasions, C. hominis has been isolated from other body sites (77). Most reported C. valvarum endocarditis cases were of odontogenic origin, related to periodontal diseases (78).

sect1.title: Chromobacterium spp.
sect1.para: Localized infections withC. violaceum usually arise from contaminated wounds; septicemia with multiple organ abscesses may follow. These infections are significantly associated with neutrophil dysfunction (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency and chronic granulomatous disease). Children without these conditions and those with bacteremia show a high fatality rate (44). Some infections with C. violaceum have been observed in Europe as well (79, 80). A number of virulence factors other than endotoxin, i.e., adhesins, invasins, and cytolytic proteins, have been described (81). C. haemolyticum can cause bacteremia after trauma and exposure to water (45).

sect1.title: Dysgonomonas spp.
sect1.para: D. capnocytophagoides has been associated with human disease, mainly chronic diarrhea; in a systematic search in stool samples, D. capnocytophagoides was present in 1.1 to 2.3% but was considered to be the cause of diarrhea in less than half of them (82). Bacteremia occurs as well (46, 83). D. mossii was isolated from blood of a patient with cholangitis and from the intestinal juice of a patient with pancreatic carcinoma (84, 85). D. gadei has been isolated from a human gallbladder (23) and from blood (86), and D. hofstadii has been isolated from a wound (25).

sect1.title: Eikenella corrodens
sect1.para: E. corrodens is associated with juvenile and adult periodontitis but is also an agent of infections of the upper respiratory tract, pleura and lungs, abdomen, joints, bones, and wounds (e.g., from a human bite), endocarditis, and, rarely, other infections like dacryocystitis (3, 57, 87). These are often indolent and mixed with other members of the oropharyngeal microbiota, particularly staphylococci and streptococci. Risk factors are dental manipulations and intravenous drug use. E. corrodens can trigger a cascade of events that induce inflammation in periodontal tissue (88). Infections with the other Eikenella spp. are infrequent. E. exigua has been found mainly in abscesses (26).

sect1.title: Kingella spp.
sect1.para: Infections withK. kingae show a predilection for bones and joints of previously healthy children under 4 years of age (28). The use of culture and broad-range bacterial and K. kingae-specific nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) show it to be the most common cause of osteoarthritic infection in this age group (89). Septic arthritis, discitis, and osteomyelitis of the lower extremities as well as occult bacteremia are conspicuous. Stomatitis and/or upper respiratory infections may precede systemic disease, suggesting entry through a damaged mucosa (28). In adults, systemic infections occur in immunocompromised individuals (28), or they may present as endocarditis (3). Virulence factors are an RTX toxin, polysaccharide capsule, and type IV pili (28).

K. denitrificans has been reported as an agent of endocarditis (3). K. oralis has been isolated from patients with periodontitis, but its relationship to the disease is unclear. K. potus has caused a wound infection following a kinkajou bite (28).

sect1.title: Pasteurella spp.
sect1.para: Human isolates ofP. multocida are mostly found in wound or soft tissue infections. Less frequent are colonization or infection of the respiratory tract and (by hematogenous or contiguous route) systemic disease, such as meningitis, dialysis-associated peritonitis, endocarditis, endograft infection, osteomyelitis, conjunctivitis, endophthalmitis, urinary tract infection, uterine abscess, intrapelvic abscess, and septicemia, with cirrhosis of the liver being a particular risk factor (36, 90–98). The subspecies most frequently encountered is P. multocida subsp. multocida, which is also more frequent in respiratory infections and bacteremias than P. multocida subsp. septica, which is most often associated with wound infections and central nervous system infections (34). In the respiratory tract, colonization may eventually lead to sinusitis or bronchitis as well as pneumonia and empyema, the latter two mostly in patients with prior respiratory disease (90). Virulence factors are capsules (five serotypes, of which A and D account for most human isolates), lipopolysaccharide, sialidases, hyaluronidase, surface adhesins, iron acquisition proteins (99), and the P. multocida toxin, a highly potent mitogen (95). Cases of human infection with P. canis (from dogs), P. dagmatis, and P. stomatis (from dogs or cats) are infrequent (100, 101); however, P. canis is the most common species isolated from infected dog bite wounds (34). P. dagmatis has been reported in systemic infections such as pneumonia, peritonitis, septicemia, and endocarditis; furthermore, P. dagmatis can cause exacerbation of bronchiectasis symptoms in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (100). Prosthetic valve endocarditis caused by a P. dagmatis-like isolate originating from a patient’s cat was described (102). In some cases of pasteurellosis, animal contact could not be established (103). Double infections with two Pasteurella spp. have also been observed (100). Of the related species, (P.) aerogenes has caused wound infections from pig and hamster bites (34, 104), (P.) bettyae has been found in infections of newborns and in infections of the male and female genital tracts (105), and (P.) caballi has been isolated from horse bites (34). (P.) pneumotropica, reclassified as Rodentibacter pneumotropicus, is a rare agent of systemic infection in humans (30). Cases of human infection with Avibacterium gallinarum, Bibersteinia trehalosi, Gallibacterium anatis, Mannheimia haemolytica, and Mannheimia glucosida, all formerly in the genus Pasteurella, and with related species are reported (106, 107).

sect1.title: Simonsiella spp.
sect1.para: S. muelleri has not been associated with disease. Simonsiella can be encountered in exfoliative cytology specimens of the upper gastrointestinal tract and with erosions of the oral mucosa and the respiratory tract and should not be confused with a truly pathogenic organism (108).

sect1.title: Streptobacillus spp.
sect1.para: S. moniliformis infection, commonly called rat bite fever, is a systemic illness beginning with fever and chills, followed by migratory, sometimes even suppurative, polyarthritis and a maculopapular rash on the extremities. Rare complications include endocarditis, myo- or pericarditis, pneumonia, septicemia, and abscess formation (31, 49, 109). Streptobacillus hongkongensis, reclassified as Pseudostreptobacillus hongkongensis, has been isolated from patients with arthritis (32, 110).

sect1.title: Suttonella indologenes
sect1.para: Human isolates ofS. indologenes have been very rare: they have been isolated form ocular sources (57), peritoneal dialysis fluid, and blood cultures in a case of endocarditis (40, 111).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Collection of specimens and transport should follow the guidelines described inchapter 19 of this Manual; the low viability of many species makes the use of transport media, e.g., eSwab (Copan Diagnostics Inc., Murrieta, CA), whenever indicated, mandatory. Cultures of most bacteria described in this chapter can be stored at room temperature for 1 to 2 weeks. However, for some other very fastidious bacteria, e.g., C. canimorsus, subcultures must be performed frequently. For keeping strains in a culture collection, the isolates should be frozen in a cryoprotective solution, e.g., skim milk, at −70°C.

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: Direct microscopy of specimens or of positive blood cultures supported by clinical information may help identify the corresponding bacteria, e.g., the typical morphology of spindle-shaped cells in the Gram stain in the context of a dog bite allows the presumptive identification ofC. canimorsus. In blood culture-negative endocarditis, microscopy of the resected valve along with 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing of the valve or emboli allowed diagnosis (112). When the question of whether an isolate is a Gram-negative coccus or coccobacillus arises, a penicillin disk can be added to the agar plate after streaking with the isolate. After incubation, the Gram stain from growth around the disk shows coccoid forms in the case of typical Neisseria spp.; otherwise, long rods are observed (113).
Actinobacillus spp. are medium-sized, Gram-negative, rod-shaped or coccoid bacteria with a tendency to bipolar staining. Their arrangement is single, in pairs, and, rarely, in short chains.

Aggregatibacter spp. are coccoid to rod-shaped Gram-negative bacteria, occasionally exhibiting filamentous forms. A commercial NAAT-based hybridization assay for the detection of A. actinomycetemcomitans and other periodontal pathogenic bacteria (e.g., E. corrodens and Capnocytophaga spp.) is available (114).

Capnocytophaga spp. are mainly fusiform, medium-to-long cells with tapered ends (Fig. 1a). Leptotrichia buccalis is a long, fusiform, Gram-negative rod with one tapered and one square end (Fig. 1b). Differentiation is supported by biochemical reactions; lactic acid is the major fermentation end product of L. buccalis, and succinic acid is the major fermentation end product of Capnocytophaga spp. (57). C. canimorsus can also be detected by 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing (115).

Cardiobacterium spp. are pleomorphic on blood agar. C. hominis stains irregularly and appears as straight, Gram-negative rods in short chains, pairs, or rosettes, sometimes with bulbous ends; occasionally, filaments are formed. On chocolate agar, this morphology is less distinct than on blood agar. In culture-negative cases, 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing of valve or emboli have led to the diagnosis (112).
C. violaceum is a medium-sized, Gram-negative rod or coccus that is motile by one polar flagellum and one to four lateral flagella (20). C. haemolyticum forms regular Gram-negative rods (21).

Dysgonomonas spp. are small, Gram-negative rods or cocci similar to Moraxella spp. (Fig. 1c) (22). In contrast to coccoid Neisseria spp., these two genera show long rods in the Gram stain from growth around the penicillin disk (113).
E. corrodens is a slender, straight, small, Gram-negative rod with rounded ends (Fig. 1d). A specific NAAT is also commercially available (114).

Kingella spp. are short, Gram-negative rods with square ends that lie together in pairs or clusters (Fig. 1e). They tend to decolorize unevenly on Gram stains. NAAT can be used to detect K. kingae-specific sequences in culture-negative osteoarticular specimens (89).

Pasteurella spp. are small, Gram-negative rods or cocci that occur singly, in pairs, or in short chains. Bipolar staining is frequent. “Related” species are more rod-like. A NAAT for their detection is mainly applied in the veterinary field (116).

Simonsiella spp. are Gram-negative, crescent-shaped rods (0.5 to 1.0 μm long) arranged in multicellular filaments (10 to 50 μm by 2 to 8 μm) and segmented into groups of mostly 8 cells, resulting in a caterpillar-like appearance. The long axis of each cell is perpendicular to the long axis of the filament. Incomplete decolorization on Gram stains is common (108).

S. moniliformis is a Gram-negative rod with a variable morphology. Depending on age and culture conditions, cells may appear as straight, small to medium-size rods or as 100- to 150-μm-long tangled chains and filaments with bulbar swellings (Fig. 1f). In culture-negative cases, 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing has been employed (117).
S. indologenes is a plump, irregularly staining Gram-negative rod; occasionally, pairs, chains, or rosettes are formed.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: For culture of members of this group, the use of blood or chocolate agar and, wherever normal microbiota and specific bacteria are suspected, of selective media is mandatory. Most of these organisms are facultatively anaerobic and do not grow on MacConkey agar. HACEK members do not need more than 5 days of incubation in modern blood culture systems (118). Actinobacillus spp. and Aggregatibacter spp. require enriched media and grow best in a 5 to 10% CO2 atmosphere. Some A. aphrophilus strains and A. segnis require V factor; none requires hemin. Selective media for A. actinomycetemcomitans have employed bacitracin and vancomycin (119). Primary isolation of Capnocytophaga spp. requires 5 to 10% CO2 and enriched media; the composition of the blood agar base influences the ability to grow (120). For detection in mixed cultures, selective media containing bacitracin, polymyxin B, vancomycin, and trimethoprim have been used (121), as have Thayer-Martin and Martin-Lewis agar (17). C. canimorsus has most often been isolated from blood cultures. However, it may not be detected by commonly used automated blood culture systems; therefore, clinicians should inform the laboratory about risk factors for C. canimorsus infection so that subcultures on enriched media can be performed in a blind manner (120). Cardiobacterium spp. mostly requires 5 to 10% CO2 and humidity for initial growth on blood agar. Cardiobacterium spp. have most often been isolated from blood. C. violaceum grows on routine media, even on most enteric ones, at 30 to 35°C, its optimal temperature (20). C. haemolyticum grows on the same media (21).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 (a) Capnocytophaga ochracea. Gram stain of a 48-h culture grown on sheep blood agar. (b) Leptotrichia buccalis. Gram stain of a 48-h culture grown on sheep blood agar. (c) Dysgonomonas capnocytophagoides. Gram stain of a 48-h culture grown on sheep blood agar. (d) Eikenella corrodens. Gram stain of a 48-h culture grown on sheep blood agar. (e) Kingella kingae. Gram stain of a 48-h culture grown in Trypticase soy broth. (f) Streptobacillus moniliformis. Gram stain of a 48-h culture grown on sheep blood agar. Images from the Institute of Medical Microbiology, University of Zurich, Switzerland.

sect2.para: Dysgonomonas spp. grow slowly on blood agar in a CO2-enriched atmosphere (22). A selective medium containing cefoperazone, vancomycin, and amphotericin B has been used for stool culture (83). With a few exceptions, E. corrodens requires hemin for growth, unless 5 to 10% CO2 is present (20). E. corrodens grows well on commercial Columbia agar (120). Recovery of K. kingae from body fluids and pus can be difficult, because these specimens seem to be inhibitory. For isolation from mixed cultures, media containing clindamycin or vancomycin as well as Thayer-Martin agar have been recommended (20). Inoculation of body fluids into various blood culture media improves the detection rate (28). In contrast to some Haemophilus spp., Pasteurella spp. are hemin and CO2 independent and therefore grow on media without blood. “Related” species may even grow on enteric media (11). S. muelleri grows aerobically on blood agar. There are no enrichment procedures for Simonsiella, but an isolation method with tryptic soy broth without dextrose agar has been described (20). S. moniliformis is best isolated from blood, joint fluid, or abscess material. For culture, media enriched with sheep, horse, rabbit blood (15% seems to be optimal), serum, or ascitic fluid and a 5 to 10% CO2 atmosphere at 37°C are required. Sodium polyanethol sulfonate in blood culture media is inhibitory (49). S. hongkongensis grows on sheep blood Columbia agar in an anaerobic environment or under aerobic conditions with 5% CO2 (110). S. indologenes grows slowly on blood agar. Aerobic growth is enhanced by high humidity and CO2, which makes the organism appear to be facultatively anaerobic (19).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Phenotypic identification of fastidious Gram-negative rods presents several challenges. Triple sugar iron or Kligler’s agar may not support growth of fastidious genera (e.g.,Eikenella). Media should be rich in peptones (e.g., cystine Trypticase agar); the inoculum should be large (cell paste or agar blocks). Unsupplemented media used to check acid formation from carbohydrates may yield false-negative reactions. Gas formation from carbohydrates is scant or absent for most species. Indole may have to be extracted with xylene. Furthermore, phenotypic characteristics used for identification are subject to variation and dependent on individual interpretation and expertise. Correct identification to the species level often requires multiple substrates that may not be available to routine laboratories (57) and may not be provided by automated systems (2). However, the VITEK 2 Neisseria-Haemophilus identification card (VITEK 2 ID-NH card; BioMérieux, Marcy l’Etoile, France) allows the identification of most bacteria of the HACEK group (2). Pasteurella spp. are not in the database of the VITEK 2 ID-NH card but are in the database of the identification card for Gram-negative bacilli (VITEK 2 ID-GNB card; BioMérieux) (1). See chapter 34 for dichotomous identification algorithms for Gram-negative bacteria. Determination of key reactions may be used for a rapid presumptive identification, e.g., with API NH (BioMérieux) (122).

A positive ornithine decarboxylase reaction and missing sugar acidification in the cystine-Trypticase agar are typical forE. corrodens. A blood culture isolate with a positive indole reaction and a negative catalase is diagnostic for C. hominis. P. multocida has a typical pattern of acidification of sugars and a positive indole reaction, and together with a history of cat bite, the diagnosis is feasible (113). MALDI-TOF MS can be used to identify HACEK group members (5, 6). The species included in the databases of the two MALDI-TOF MS systems, i.e., the VITEK MS system (BioMérieux, Marcy l’Etoile, France) and the Bruker MALDI Biotyper (Bruker Daltonik GmbH, Bremen, Germany), are mentioned below. Accurate identification of fastidious Gram-negative rods is important, when isolated from normally sterile body sites, to inform appropriate patient management. In view of the phenotypical closeness of the species, molecular methods (e.g., 16S rRNA gene or rpoB gene PCR/sequencing) may be needed for species identification of Actinobacillus, Aggregatibacter, Capnocytophaga, and Pasteurella spp. (4, 6, 106). Furthermore, molecular methods can identify new species in association with clinical entities. Colonies of Actinobacillus spp. are approximately 2 mm in diameter after 24 h growth at 37°C, smooth or rough, viscous, and often adherent to the agar. Smooth colonies are dome shaped and have a bluish hue when viewed by transmitted light. Biochemical reactions are listed in Table 1.

table.title: TABLE 1 Biochemical reactions of Actinobacillus and Aggregatibacter speciesa

sect2.para: aData are from references 12, 41, 42, 57, and 113. +, ≥90% of strains positive; −, ≥90% of strains negative; D, delayed reaction; ONPG, ortho-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside; v, variable; w, weak; /, or. All species are indole negative, reduce nitrate to nitrite, and are positive for alkaline phosphatase; ND, no data.

bA decisive phenotypic test for identification of A. kilianii sp. nov. is alanine-phenylalanine-proline arylamidase as tested by the VITEK 2 ID-NH card, which is positive for A. kilianii and negative for the three other Aggregatibacter spp.; A. kilianii can be distinguished from A. aphrophilus and A. segnis by testing acid production from N-acetylglucosamine and can be distinguished from A. actinomycetemcomitans by testing for catalase and β-galactosidase (ONPG); A. actinomycetemcomitans and A. kilianii produce acid from N-acetylglucosamine, whereas A. aphrophilus and A. segnis do not (12).

SomeActinobacillus spp. are included in both MALDI-TOF MS databases. A. ureae is included in the VITEK 2 ID-NH card database. A. actinomycetemcomitans colonies initially show a central dot and a slightly irregular edge and, on further incubation, develop a star-like configuration resembling “crossed cigars” and pit the agar. After several subcultures, this rough morphology may give way to smooth and opaque, nonpitting colonies, reflecting loss of fimbriae. In liquid media, the bacterium forms granules which adhere to the sides and to the bottom of the tube. Colonies of other Aggregatibacter spp. are granular or smooth, grayish white to yellowish, and opaque; without CO2, there is pleomorphism, with small and large colonies. For species identification, a battery of tests (requirements for V and X factors, biochemical tests, and colony morphology [Table 1]) is necessary to avoid confusion with Haemophilus spp.

table.title: TABLE 2 Biochemical reactions of Capnocytophaga, Dysgonomonas and related species, and Streptobacillus moniliformisa

sect2.para: aData are from references 13, 23, 25, 57, and 113. +, ≥90% of strains positive; −, ≥90% of strains negative; ND, no data; v, variable. All species are negative for urease and ornithine decarboxylase and form acid from glucose (sometimes only with addition of serum).
bC. periodontitidis is positive for the urease reaction; the other Capnocytophaga spp. are urease negative (13).
cThe isolates of D. gadei were catalase and indole positive (23, 86). D. mossii and D. hofstadii (one strain) differ in a few reactions in the API Rapid ID32A system (25).
dONPG, ortho-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside.

Aggregatibacter spp. have negative reactions for production of indole, ornithine decarboxylase, and urease and are not dependent on X factor, whereas Haemophilus spp. are positive for at least one of these three reactions or cannot synthesize heme components from δ-aminolevulinic acid. Automated systems may present difficulties in identifying these bacteria to the species level (2, 61). A. segnis is best identified by a specific NAAT (61). Aggregatibacter spp., except for A. kilianii, mentioned in Table 1 are included in both MALDI-TOF MS databases (5, 6) as well as in the VITEK 2 ID-NH card database (2). A decisive phenotypic test for identification of A. kilianii sp. nov. is alanine-phenylalanine-proline arylamidase as tested by the VITEK 2 ID-NH card, which is positive for A. kilianii and negative for the three other Aggregatibacter spp. A. kilianii can be separated from A. aphrophilus and A. segnis by testing acid production from the N-acetylglucosamine; A. actinomycetemcomitans and A. kilianii produce acid from N-acetylglucosamine whereas A. aphrophilus and A. segnis do not. A. kilianii can be separated from A. actinomycetemcomitans by testing for catalase and β-galactosidase (ortho-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside [ONPG]) (Table 1) (12).

Colonies ofCapnocytophaga spp. on blood agar are very small after 24 h at 37°C and reach 2 to 4 mm in diameter after 2 to 4 days; they are convex or flat and often slightly yellow when scraped off agar, show regular or spreading edges with gliding motility, and adhere to the agar surface (17). Phenotypic differentiation of species in the oxidase-negative group may be inconclusive due to the similarity of many biochemical reactions (Table 2) and the lack of suitable substrates even in automated systems (2). This has frequently given rise to identification as a Capnocytophaga sp. At present, 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing is the best diagnostic tool (4, 123). All Capnocytophaga spp. mentioned in Table 2 are included in the database of the Bruker MALDI Biotyper (6), and some of these species are in the database of the VITEK MS system. The VITEK 2 ID-NH card database includes Capnocytophaga spp. at the genus level (4). The new species C. periodontitidis is not yet in the databases, but the positive urease reaction separates it from other Capnocytophaga spp. (13).

Colonies ofCardiobacterium spp. attain a diameter of approximately 1 mm after 48 h at 37°C on blood agar; they are circular, smooth, and opaque, and they may pit the agar. Biochemical tests are shown in Table 3. Differences between the two species are minimal and include indole production in some strains, mannitol fermentation, and quantitative composition of cellular fatty acids (18). Some automated systems may misidentify C. valvarum (122). Both species are included in databases of the Bruker MALDI Biotyper (5, 6). The VITEK 2 ID-NH card database includes C. hominis (2). Colonies of C. violaceum measure 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h of growth, are round and smooth, have an almond-like smell, and may be beta-hemolytic. Most strains produce a violet pigment called violacein, which is soluble in ethanol but not in water. Identification is easy if this pigment is produced, although the positive oxidase reaction will only be detected by a modified technique (124). C. haemolyticum does not form a pigment. Biochemical reactions of both are listed in Table 3. C. violaceum is included in both MALDI-TOF MS databases and in the VITEK 2 ID-GNB card. C. haemolyticum is not in the MS databases and cannot be separated from C. violaceum by these systems (21).

Colonies ofDysgonomonas spp. are entire, measure 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h of growth, have a strawberry-like odor, and do not spread or adhere. The species show few biochemical differences (Table 2). Aerobically growing isolates of L. buccalis may be confused with Dysgonomonas spp.; microscopic examination of morphology, different cellular fatty acid profiles, and determination of the production of lactic acid from glucose in Leptotrichia spp. (Dysgonomonas spp. produce propionic and succinic acid) (57) are helpful if 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing is not available (23, 25, 57). Dysgonomonas spp. are not yet in the MALDI-TOF MS or the VITEK 2 card database.

table.title: TABLE 3 Biochemical reactions of some rod-shaped species of the Neisseriaceae and of the Cardiobacteriaceaea

sect2.para: aData are from references 18, 21, 26–29, 57, 78, and 113. +, ≥90% of strains positive; −, ≥90% of strains negative; G, gas; LD, lysine decarboxylase; ND, no data; TMA, Thayer-Martin agar; v, variable; w, weak. All species are negative for urease and acid production from lactose and D-xylose.
bE. halliae cannot be separated by conventional reactions. E. glucosivorans produces acid from glucose; E. exigua and E. longinqua are strictly anaerobic and oxidase positive (26, 27).
cK. negevensis is negative for alkaline phosphatase and acid production from maltose (29).
dSome strains form small amounts of gas.
eWeakly positive reactions may be observed in oxidative/fermentative (O/F) media.

Colonies ofE. corrodens are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 48 h of growth, show clear centers that are often surrounded by spreading growth, may pit the agar, and assume a slightly yellow hue after several days. In liquid media, granules are produced. Typical isolates fail to form acid from carbohydrates in nonsupplemented media and are ornithine decarboxylase and nitrate positive; lysine decarboxylase activity is variable (Table 3). E. corrodens grows poorly or not at all on triple sugar-iron or Kligler’s agar. E. corrodens is well identified by the VITEK 2 ID-NH card and by MALDI-TOF MS (2, 5, 6). The new Eikenella spp. are not yet in the databases.

Kingella colonies on blood agar in 5 to 10% CO2 (which enhances growth) are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 48 h of growth. One type is smooth with a central papilla, and the other is spreading and pits the medium. Only K. kingae shows a small but distinct zone of hemolysis on blood agar. Colonies have a short viability and have to be subcultured frequently. Biochemical test results are listed in Table 3. In addition to microscopic and colonial morphology, the tests serve to separate kingellae from rod-shaped members of the genus Neisseria (Table 4), with which they may be confused using automated systems (2). Since K. denitrificans may grow on Thayer-Martin or Martin-Lewis agar (20), it may be misidentified as Neisseria gonorrhoeae unless the catalase reaction, which is negative for Kingella, is performed. Kingella spp. are in both MALDI-TOF MS databases as well as in the VITEK 2 ID-NH card database. K. kingae is well identified by the VITEK 2 ID-NH card and by MALDI-TOF MS (2, 5, 6). K. negevensis is not yet in the databases.

Colonies ofPasteurella spp. are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h of growth at 37°C and are opaque and greyish. Encapsulated strains tend to be mucoid. A slight greening underneath the colonies may be noted. Indole-positive isolates exhibit a mouselike odor. Biochemical reactions are listed in Table 5. The oxidase test has to be performed on blood agar; a weak reaction after 30 s is characteristic of many Pasteurella spp. (125). Nutritionally fastidious, nonmotile strains of Enterobacteriaceae, e.g., Escherichia coli, may be misidentified as Pasteurella spp. unless an oxidase test is performed. In view of the phenotypic closeness of some taxa (http://www.bacterio.net), species identification in automated systems may be unsatisfactory (1, 100, 101). 16S rRNA gene and sodA gene PCR/sequencing have provided reliable species identification, the latter with even more discriminatory power (106). All Pasteurella spp. mentioned in Table 5 are included in the database of the Bruker MALDI Biotyper, and some Pasteurella spp. are included in the database of the Biotype VITEK MS system (1, 6). The VITEK 2 ID-GNB card includes Pasteurella spp. (1).

table.title: TABLE 4 Differentiation between Kingella and rod-shaped Neisseria speciesa

sect2.para: aData are from references 20, 28, and 57. +, ≥90% of strains positive; −, ≥90% of strains negative; ND, no data available; v, variable; w, weak.
bNeisseria zoodegmatis (EF-4b) is negative.
cN. zoodegmatis positive only in O/F media (oxidative).

Colonies ofSimonsiella sp. are 1 to 2 mm in diameter after 24 h, may show gliding motility, and produce a pale-yellow pigment. S. muelleri is beta-hemolytic. Biochemical tests are listed in Table 3. Simonsiella spp. are not yet in the MALDI-TOF MS databases or the databases of the VITEK 2 cards. S. moniliformis may show wild-type and L-phase colonies in the same culture. The former are 1 to 3 mm in diameter after 48 to 72 h of growth on blood agar and are round and smooth. L-phase colonies grow better on clear media, yielding a “fried egg” appearance, with irregular outlines and coarse lipid globules. In liquid media, growth occurs mainly in the form of “puff balls” at the bottom of the tube. The organism dies quickly unless subcultured (49). It is biochemically inert; glucose is acidified weakly and in a delayed fashion (Table 2). Fatty acid analysis can confirm the diagnosis, as can 16S rRNA gene PCR/sequencing (57, 117). S. moniliformis is included in the database of the Bruker MALDI Biotyper. Colonies of S. indologenes may spread or pit the agar surface of blood agar. Biochemical tests are listed in Table 3. S. indologenes is included in both MALDI-TOF MS databases.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS AND SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: On the basis of surface polysaccharides, six serotypes ofA. actinomycetemcomitans can be distinguished, of which a, b, and c are most common. Serotype b is associated with periodontitis, endocarditis, and penicillin resistance; serotype c, with periodontal health and extraoral infections (126). Capsular serotyping of C. canimorsus has been done by PCR and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs); C. canimorsus from dogs has 9 different serovars (A to I) of capsular polysaccharide, which are implicated in resistance to the innate immune system of the host. However, only three serovars (A, B, and C) cover 88% of human isolates (127). For E. corrodens, typing has been done by arbitrarily primed PCR demonstrating unstable clonality of E. corrodens in the oral cavity (128). For typing of Pasteurella spp., PCR profiling, restriction endonuclease analysis, ribotyping, multilocus sequence typing, and pulsed-field gel electrophoresis have been employed (129).
Detection of antibodies directed against any of the bacteria discussed in this chapter has been studied on a small scale only and does not seem to offer much value.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY
sect2.para: Approved guidelines for broth microdilution susceptibility testing of the HACEK group and for antimicrobial dilution and disk susceptibility testing ofPasteurella spp. have been published by CLSI (130) (see chapter 77 of this Manual). Beta-lactamase production among members of the HACEK group is well documented, and beta-lactamase-producing isolates are ampicillin resistant. Some isolates may be resistant to ampicillin due to mechanisms other than beta-lactamase production; routine performance of a beta-lactamase test is recommended for all HACEK isolates (130). The European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) has published breakpoints for antimicrobial dilution and disk susceptibility testing of K. kingae and P. multocida; for all other species, EUCAST has defined non-species-related pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) breakpoints (131).

Susceptibility studies ofActinobacillus spp. are extant for a few isolates of the human-pathogenic species that are susceptible to many antimicrobials, including penicillin (42, 53). Aggregatibacter spp. are susceptible to cephalosporins, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides (3). Resistance to ampicillin is common, but amoxicillin combined with a beta-lactamase inhibitor has been effective (130). An in-house investigation of 18 strains of A. aphrophilus revealed susceptibility to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and fluoroquinolones. Capnocytophaga spp. are usually susceptible to broad-spectrum cephalosporins, carbapenems, clindamycin, tetracyclines, and fluoroquinolones but are resistant to aminoglycosides (63). Macrolide resistance is highly prevalent in human oral Capnocytophaga spp. (132). Multidrug-resistant isolates have occasionally been encountered (62, 133). C. hominis and C. valvarum are susceptible to many antimicrobials, including penicillin (18). Beta-lactamase production is rare, and its effect can be neutralized by clavulanic acid (130, 134). C. violaceum is resistant to many antimicrobials (beta-lactams and colistin) but is mostly susceptible to imipenem, fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (135). C. haemolyticum has a similar resistance pattern (21). D. capnocytophagoides strains are susceptible to tetracyclines, clindamycin, macrolides, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, whereas they are resistant to cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, and fluoroquinolones and variably susceptible to other beta-lactam antibiotics and to imipenem (82, 83).

table.title: TABLE 5 Biochemical reactions of human Pasteurella and related speciesa

sect2.para: aData are from references 7, 11, 30, 41, 47, and 57. +, ≥90% of strains positive; −, ≥90% of strains negative; v, variable; w, weak. All species reduce nitrate to nitrite and are negative for arginine dihydrolase and esculin hydrolysis.

bP. multocida subsp. multocida, P. multocida subsp. septica, and P. multocida subsp. gallicida can be separated on the basis of sorbitol and dulcitol fermentation (+/− in P. multocida subsp. multocida, −/− in P. multocida subsp. septica, and +/+ in the mostly avian P. multocida subsp. gallicida); weakly sorbitol-positive strains of P. multocida subsp. multocida can be recognized by a specific PCR profile (57, 140).
cNew genera or reclassifications may be necessary for species designated by “(P.)” (104).

E. corrodens is generally susceptible to penicillin, amoxicillin/clavulanate, piperacillin/tazobactam, ceftriaxone, meropenem, and moxifloxacin but is resistant to clindamycin (136). An in-house investigation of 23 strains of E. corrodens showed susceptibility to tetracycline, ciprofloxacin, and levofloxacin. Beta-lactamase-positive strains have been reported, but the enzyme was inhibited by beta-lactamase inhibitors (130). Kingella spp. are generally susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics, macrolides, tetracyclines, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and fluoroquinolones (28). Beta-lactamase-positive isolates susceptible to beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor combinations have been reported (28). In a retrospective survey of 83 endocarditis cases, the therapy was mostly with beta-lactams, in 16 cases followed by ciprofloxacin and in 12 cases combined with other antibiotics, mostly aminoglycosides (137). Pasteurella spp. are generally susceptible to penicillin, broad-spectrum cephalosporins, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and azithromycin but resistant to clindamycin (136, 138). Rare penicillin-resistant isolates of Pasteurella spp. have been encountered, but they are susceptible to beta-lactam–beta-lactamase inhibitor combinations (130). For isolates of Pasteurella spp. from bite wounds, routine susceptibility testing is usually not necessary; multiple organisms are often present in these specimens. Empiric therapy directed toward these organisms is generally effective for P. multocida as well (130). S. muelleri is not yet an established pathogenic bacterium, and susceptibility data are scarce.

S. moniliformis is susceptible to penicillin and tetracyclines, the mainstays of treatment, and to cephalosporins, carbapenems, aztreonam, clindamycin, erythromycin, and tetracycline; it shows intermediate susceptibility to aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones and is resistant to colistin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (49). Patients with S. moniliformis endocarditis require dual therapy with high-dose penicillin G in combination with an aminoglycoside; the use of an aminoglycoside appears to enhance activity against the cell wall-deficient “L” forms of S. moniliformis (49, 117). Susceptibility of S. indologenes resembles that of HACEK bacteria (40).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Some bacteria of this group are colonizers of the human or animal oral cavity; therefore, the evaluation of their presence in clinical specimens may be difficult. If those bacteria are isolated as pure cultures from normally sterile body sites, they should be interpretated as infectious agents and reported with the susceptibility testing results. In specimens normally containing aerobic and anaerobic microbiota members, e.g., from anatomical structures adjacent to the oral cavity, as well as from wounds, e.g., bite wounds, bacteria discussed in this chapter can be innocent bystanders or infectious agents. If these fastidious Gram-negative rods are predominant, i.e., other mixed aerobic and anaerobic microbiota members are present only in a minority, their identification to the species level and susceptibility testing are warranted. Even if typical pathogenic bacteria, e.g.,Staphylococcus aureus or beta-hemolytic streptococci, are predominant, the additional presence of fastidious Gram-negative rods can be relevant; the common empirical therapy with clindamycin for oral infections can select clindamycin-resistant E. corrodens (139). In such and similar situations, close cooperation between the microbiology laboratory and the physician is necessary to discuss a repeat culture of the fastidious Gram-negative rods for an identification to the species level and susceptibility testing.
